Silicon carbide, also known as carborundum or SiC, is a compound made up of silicon and carbon atoms bonded together in a crystal lattice. The material was first discovered by Edward G. Acheson in 1891 when he attempted to create artificial diamonds using electricity to heat a mix of clay (aluminum silicate) and powdered coke (carbon). Instead, the result was an incredibly hard material that had many properties similar to those of industrial diamonds.

Silicon carbide has several advantages over other materials due to its unique properties:

1. Hardness: Silicon carbide has a Mohs hardness rating of 9 out of 10 which gives it its nickname “carborundum.” This level is comparable only to tungsten carbide and corundum (Al2O3), making it well-suited for tasks such as grinding and cutting tools.
 
2. Thermal conductivity: High thermal conductivity allows silicon carbide materials to perform well under high temperatures without losing their mechanical integrity.

3. Electrical conductivity: SiC can act as a semiconductor depending on how it's doped during production which makes it suitable for use in electronic devices requiring high-temperature resistance or radiation protection.

4. Chemical stability: Silicon carbide is chemically inert.Resistance against harsh chemicals make them ideal for use-cases like seals or bearings exposed environments where corrosive agents are encountered

5 .Wear resistance :More durable than others ceramics.They have less wear down rate due long-term usage 

6.Heat shock resistance - Can withstand sudden fluctuations thereby enabling engines & exhaust systems manufacturers rely upon these once designed become more efficient
